turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Charles Townsend, Petitioner, versus Frank G. Sain, Sheriff of Cook County.
Mr. Leighton.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

The principal federal question presented in this case is whether the Fourteenth Amendment to our federal constitution allows the State of Illinois to inject a drug into petitioner to quiet, sedate him, and affect his mind, and then use a confession taken from him while he is under the drug thus injected and convict him of murder.

This Court has granted a certiorari to review the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in which the judgment of the District Court, dismissing an application for habeas corpus under the Federal Habeas Corpus Act, was affirmed.

Illinois proceedings had been exhausted by the petitioner and because the statement of the historical facts will necessarily involve a discussion of all the procedural questions, I will go directly to the facts that give rise to these proceedings.
On January 1, 1954, the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was there a hearing on this case below, any kind of a hearing?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: There was a review of the complete record of the state proceedings Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But no -- but no supplemental testimony taken?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: None, whatever.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Was there any request?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: There was You Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: There was.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You'll come to that I guess.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: And I will touch upon that because that is important in view of the opinion of the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And since -- since you're being interrupted at the outset, may I put to one side, there's no suggestion in this case that the confession was due or the result of excessive retention during which the petitioner was applied to improper question.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: There is that contention Your Honor.
There is that contention.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it's not in your question presented Mr. Leighton.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well in the question presented, if Your Honor please, we stated broad enough to include the claim we had made in the Supreme Court of Illinois that the period of interrogation was excessive in view of the injection of the drug.
That is, if I may say again Your Honor, that is the position of the petition there is involved in this case and within the question presented.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't think it's worthwhile taking your time if it is concluded in your question, but for me, those are -- and I take it for you distinct question namely was he under -- was he under extensive questioning, whatever the conditions of the questioning maybe, and was the injection of this drug in and of itself an impairment of his mind such as to preclude of finding of voluntariness?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Those are two different questions?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: They are -- they are different, however --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I was, reading the question presented, which I did a few minutes ago, I -- I didn't get the impression that will raise excessive detention as a separate claim but maybe you did?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: No.
Not as a separate claim but included in the broad question presented if Your Honor please.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They -- alright, you come to it, but it's -- how many hours all total -- what length of time was he under questioning, Mr. Leighton?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: The crucial period is 8:30 pm of January 1, 1954 and 11:15 pm, that's the crucial period.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was he questioned during that period?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: He was questioned during that period.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How long?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Apparently from all the evidence now available to us, he was questioned in sense -- incisively from approximately 8:45 to 11:15 pm.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that's the period during which the doctor came?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, but isn't the essence of your case then that the injection of this drug whether you would question three minutes or five minutes or even voluntarily, emitted his confession?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The drug impaired, whatever he said during the immediate period of its administration?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That is correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that the question of, periods of question seemed to me quite irrelevant.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Not quite irrelevant.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Right, I don't want (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: But it's not quite irrelevant but important to them.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In due course, in due course, I hope you disentangle the two questions.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: I will Your Honor.
On January 1, 1954 at about 1:45 am --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And was there -- one more thing, was there later repetition of this confession?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes there is Your Honor and I will --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Out of the period of the drug?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes there is and I will touch upon that part.
At 1:45 am, on the morning of January 1, 1954, this petitioner was seen walking on the street called 35th Street in the City of Chicago by four police officers of the City of Chicago.

There appeared to have been a man named Vernon Campbell who incidentally is named in different names in the record, Vincent Campbell or Vernon Campbell and I believe the name is Vernon, who had been in custody of the police some several days prior to January 1.
He himself had been in custody for some robbery or the crime and by the time of his testimony in this case, he was in -- on probation from a conviction of the crime of robbery.

Now, it's also fair to say that apparently during the long period of time prior to January 1, 1954 in this particular police district, they had been found several men dead, all with similar injuries on the head and the police had theorized that somewhere in this police district, there had been about a man they had designated as the house brick murder.
In interrogating Campbell, they came to the conclusion that the petitioner here, Charles Townsend, had something to do with regard to these murders.

And with Campbell to identify the petitioner, they went to 35th Indiana at about 1:45 am on New Years day, January 1, 1954 and arrested the petitioner in the company of another man whom later they dismissed.
The record is silent as to what they did with this other man.
Now, Your Honors have allowed this case to proceed on the type written record and I shall make express reference to the record where these crucial facts appear and about which there is no dispute.

Townsend was taken to the second district police station and there he was held from approximate 2:45 am until 5 am, and there is nothing important that occurred between 1:45 am and 8:30 pm that will be or will be crucial federal question presented here except for one fact.

Approximate an hour and a half, prior to the time that Townsend was arrested, he had taken a large injection of heroine and it is without dispute that for the period, from the time that he was 15 years of age until the time relevant here, he had been a confirmed narcotic addict and this fact had been so found by the Supreme Court of Illinois

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: How old was he at this time?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: He was then 19 years of age.
The fact that he had taken this injection of heroine was also known by all the arresting officers because he had told them that, and they knew that he was under the influence of this heroine.

Another relevant fact within this period to be stated, there was no dispute that Townsend at that time was of subnormal intelligence and upon examination by a prosecution witness, he was found to posses an IQ of 63 and to use the language of the (Inaudible) to examine him, he was using an old form of characterization near moron in this stage of psychiatric examination and to use the words of this prosecution witness, he was a near mental defective.
Now, between approximately 5 am on the morning of January 1, 1954 and until 8:30 pm, Townsend was not questioned.
He was held in custody and there was testimony by one of the prosecution witness that it was the desire of the police officers not to allow him to come in contact with anyone.

And so they transported him from the second police district to the 19th police district for reasons best known to police consistent with this plan of theirs not to let him come in contact with anyone.

He remained at the 19th district without being questioned by anyone although he says something about being asked some questions, but of the purpose of this case, we will agree that he was not questioned by anyone and he remained at the 19th district until about 8:30 pm when he was transferred to the second district and immediately given into their custody of the same four police officers who had arrested him.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That means that between the hour of his arrest that one or something in the morning?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: 1:45 am Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Until the following morning, he was not interrogated by any police?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Until the following evening 8:30 pm.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Until the following evening?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right sir.
Until the following evening.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: No interrogation?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: No interrogation.

He was not and we will concede in the course of this argument, no one questioned him, and no one (Inaudible) him in anyway and he remained in that station in this condition without being bothered except that he was held in custody in the way which no one could get to him, friend, counsel, otherwise.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Did anybody tried to get to him?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: No one tried and for the purpose of clarifying that question, Mr. Justice Stewart, this petitioner is a man who has no one.

Now at about 8:30 pm, he was brought back to the second district and there was short, very common in police practices in Cook County and Townsend was put in the company of three other men to be viewed by a man named Anagnost, who had been the victim of a similar incident as these victims, supposedly have been.
In the course of the show-up, Anagnost --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And may I ask whether the -- what you call a show-up, is that a line up?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But with others therefore?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: With others there.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not himself?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Not --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Somebody wasn't brought in, this the man?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: No, he was put in the company of three other men and the purpose of this show-up as the Chicago police call it, is to allow the victim of robberies otherwise some violence to pick out the (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you have no grievance about that, have you?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: We have no grievance about that Your Honor.
There is a significance to this incident which will touch upon this confession and I mention it now.

When Anagnost was there, it was for the purpose of picking the assailant in accordance with the theory of the police that it was Townsend, but when Anagnost looked over this line up, he picked out a man who was not Townsend.

Now, it is significant that when Your Honors requested the attorneys for the respondent to file an additional answer to the petition for habeas corpus, there was attached to that return, that additional answer, the confession of Charles Townsend that he robbed Gus Anagnost.
It is in fact that when Anagnost picked out the person who assaulted him with a brick, he picked out a man who was not Townsend.
Now until this moment, until the show-up, there's nothing to indicate, there's nothing with Townsend.

Immediately thereafter however, there was an attempt by Cagney, one of the arresting officers to question Townsend and Townsend complained to him that he couldn't answer any question because he was then in the throes of what is called the withdrawal symptoms of the narcotic addict.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He had the heroin on hour or two before he was arrested?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: On midnight on New Year's Eve?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And this was now New Year's night?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: 8:30 -- 8:45 pm of the same day.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The same night.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: And by this time, he was in the withdrawal symptom and Dr. Mansfield who treated him has described the physical disability of a narcotic addict in the withdrawal symptom.
He has pains, particularly abdominal pains, he sweats, he had no control of his faculties, he' over excited, he is in a complete misery.
And Cagney, the arresting officer described his condition as one in which he couldn't count how many times this petitioner bent over and wouldn't answer questions.
Now, there is a quarrel here whether it was Townsend who said to Cagney “call a doctor” or whether it was Cagney's idea.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Cagney was the police officer or --

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Cagney was the principal and the most active police officer in this investigation.

It is clear, however, that it was Cagney who called the doctor and Dr. Mansfield so testified, Officer Cagney so testified, Officer Martin so testified, Officer Fitzgerald so testified and so did Corcoran.
Cagney then called Dr. Mansfield and Dr. Mansfield --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I missed something Mr. Leighton, I missed something.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What intervene -- I mean how did Cagney come to call?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well, he was trying to question the petitioner but the petitioner couldn't answer any questions and the petitioner described his illness and he saw the petitioner bending over several times he said and he couldn't count the number of times that the petitioner bent over and so he -- he then called the doctor, his testimony appearing on page 358 to 361 of the type written record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I got the impression from the Court of Appeals' opinion that that Townsend indicated that how he felt, is that a wrong impression Mr. Leighton?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: I think Your Honor has the wrong impression about that as did the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well I don't mean that I get from the record because I haven't read that.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I got the impression from the Court of Appeals and I wondered if I got the wrong impression from them.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Oh well you got the right impressions from what they said but the record --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: -- is not correct as to that.
It was Cagney who called the doctor and it's also important this time to bear in mind that Dr. Mansfield was an employee of the Chicago Police Department.
He was as he described himself a police doctor and he was at the beck and call of the Chicago Police Department.
Townsend had nothing to do with calling Mansfield specifically.
What can be said from the evidence is that when Townsend in this -- in this fit of withdrawal syndrome, asked for some help and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He did ask?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Oh yes, he did ask and he did -- and there was -- there's some -- there's evidence here from which one could conclude that in this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that's what -- well, that's what the Court of Appeals is referring to.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes, in this colloquy --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: He said that petitioner asked to see a doctor?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's a fair statement.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: And he has the record number.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes, that's the fair statement and then it was Cagney who decided on Mansfield.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, you mean he's selected to the doctor?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: He selected the doctor, you see.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: But Townsend asked for a doctor.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Townsend asked for a doctor because there was a conversation between Cagney and Townsend about what to do and then Cagney called Mansfield.
Now the courts below, both the Seventh Circuit and the Supreme Court of Illinois have attached a great of importance to what they say, is in the record.
That when Dr. Mansfield came into the police station, he talked with no one.
The fact is the record is clear without contradiction that when he came to the station, the person who greeted him at the door was Cagney and he had the petitioner there in this particular room.

Now, relevant to this whole inquiry, it's important to remember that the record shows that in this station there were two rooms, a room which they called the center room and a room called the South room.
Townsend and Cagney were in the center room.
The State's Attorney who took the confession was in the South room.

Now, it's also important remember that at this point, when Dr. Mansfield came into the station, the State's Attorney who was there to take the confession had already been called at 8:35 pm and I point to You Honors a letter written by Mr. Janega to his superiors, in his own language saying that at 8:35 pm of January 1, 1954 he had been called to the second district in connection with this interrogation of Townsend and he had made the necessary arrangements to be there and had called the reporter and this was at 8:35 pm and this according to the un-contradicted testimonial of prosecution witnesses was before the show-up and before the doctor had been called.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Leighton, this is for me at least, a very crucial part of your -- of the case. Is there any suggestion, is there any implication in what you said that there was any kind of cahoots, I don't mean use the phrase, any kind of pre-arranging between the police in bringing a doctor there and the anticipated presence of the district attorney, anything like comparable to what we had and what is Layer?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Layer versus Deno?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well then I'll pause.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What do -- what do you claim is that?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Your Honor I devoted a great deal of time to this case and to this precise question you just asked, and I submit simply this.

It is beyond my sense of comprehension to believe that an experienced police officer like Cagney and Corcoran who were part of the homicide section of Chicago Police Department would call a doctor to the police station to inspect and examine and give therapy to a principal witness or the principal suspect to clear up six important felonies and not have in mind some relationship between the administration of the drug and the consequence that was reached.

We due respect to the judgments of all the judges below who apparently don't agree with me, I merely submit to Your Honor in answer to your question that in my judgment, a fair reading of this record is that the calling of Janega at 8:35 pm, the selection of a police doctor, the presence of Cagney in the room, the injection of drug without anything being said by the doctor to Cagney, a doctor who later said he had never seen in his life any truth serum, scopolamine although he treated him with hyoscine which according to all the pharmacological opinion in this country and in Europe is a drug which is administered in the cases of criminal investigation for the purpose of taking confessions.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I thought those two drugs were the same drug with different names?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: They are the same drug with a different names and I will touch upon that question because --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Please forgive me, I must to ask some questions about this?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there any -- any basis in the record to indicate that Cagney knew in advance their Townsend would need administration of a doctor, more particularly that a drug having -- having amnesia or potential amnesia effect would be injected?

And that this all was by way of pre-arrangement other than -- is there any evidence to indicate that all of these have anticipated that Cagney knew that it (Inaudible) found in this expressing condition, express condition, he would then the doctor and that they were a non-articulated or non-disclosed pre-arrangement?
I ask it because I see a very strongly about such a matters.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well if Your Honor please, I don't see how any other conclusion can be reached from all the facts than that.

For the simple reason that Cagney knew his condition in the early part of the day and -- and there is every reason to believe that Cagney as was well-acquainted with Mansfield as Mansfield was with the general subject of narcotic addicts in the withdrawal symptom.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is the time period, I'm quite ignorant about these things --

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- is that -- is it well-known or is there evidence (Inaudible) allowing the inference that a police official with experience would know that at a certain period, during which the withdrawal would operate deleteriously so that injection will be proper etcetera, etcetera --

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- anything like that?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, there is.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that on the record?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: In the record, there is testimony like Cagney himself that he knew at the time that he arrested Townsend.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That he was an addict?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: He was an addict.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but --

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: -- and that he had -- he had taken the injection and he knew that he was a narcotic addict.

He knew he had taken the injection you see, and my answer to Your Honor's question is that since he knew all these facts and since he knew from his experience of many years of the consequences of heroine injection in a narcotic addict, that there was a fair inference from all of this that he knew also the -- the other parts of the whole question.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was this dose an unusual dosage?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: The drug given by the doctor?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: No, the answer is yes and I'll -- and I'll now say why.
If Your Honor will look at Dr. Mansfield's testimony and it will appear on pages 210 of the record to 2 - 251 of the type written record.

He testified out of the presence of the jury on the suppression of the confession that he gave this petitioner a dosage consisting of 1/8 grain of Phenobarbital together with what he said was one-half hyoscine and he defined that mean 1/230 grain of hyoscine.
Now, that's what he said when the motion suppressed was heard.
However, in the case-in-chief, when Dr. Mansfield testified and I call Your Honors' attention to his testimony that is found on page 3 -- correction, page 981 to 991 of the record.
There, he said that he gave him 1/8 of gram of Phenobarbital and 1/230 of a gram of hyoscine.

Now, if You Honors please, that is 16 times more drug than this doctor had testified before the judge because a gram contains 15.432 grains and roughly in drug palettes, a gram has approximately 16 times more drug than a grain.

Now, before the judge and I again call Your Honors' attention that only once, only once in this doctor's testimony that he defined and that appears on 215 on the record, only once did he say that he administered 1/230 of a grain of hyoscine.

Now to answer Your Honor's question, it is generally agreed by all pharmacological experts, both in this country and in Europe, that the therapeutic dose of hyoscine within the normal range that will not completely paralyze an individual is between 1/200 of a grain and 1/100 of a grain.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Of a grain or a gram?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Of a grain.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: A grain?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: A grain you see and this -- this -- this expert that the courts below had lauded in this way testified before the judge that he gave him 1/230 of a grain, but before the jury he said that he gave him 1/230 of gram and his testimony appears on the pages I just called Your Honor's attention.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: From your point of view, his testimony was more favorable for the – for the juries than it was before the judge?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And was he -- was he cross -- was your man represented by counsel?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: He was Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Any point made of it?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: None was made strongly a bit and I can only attribute this to the fact that no one stopped to do the mathematical computation to determine that there are 15.432 grains in a gram and it was left over very easily but it's repeated, his testimony repeated again on pages 987 to 991 of the record and again, he was talking of grams and not grains.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, I may be wrong but I thought there was a clear cut issue presented to the jury that the state on the one side, that this was not only normal dosage, but less than normal dosage and on your side that it was excessive dosage.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And both those -- that issue of fact was -- it was presented to the jury and that the jury brought in the verdict that it did?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Except this Your Honor, if Your Honor will look at the instructions given to this jury, those instructions didn't touch at all upon this important pharmacological question?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Did you -- will you deny any instructions that were requested with this issue?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Your Honor I cannot answer that question because I didn't try the case and I'm only looking at the record as it's now is formed and at the time when this record was put up, at that time, we didn't have the rule we know have in Illinois that all of the instruction must be in the abstract.
Now, I might add also Your Honor that in the course of reviewing the Supreme Court of Illinois, this precise question was not analyzed as carefully as I am analyzing it here.

But I suggest to Your Honor that if you look at the instructions given to the jury and you look at the testimony, you will see that actually the import and the importance of this drug didn't occur to anybody in that case except insofar as Mr. Branion, the public defendant by instinct of his long experience had Dr. Proctor to testify about the drug.

And I suggest to you most respectively, if you look at Dr. Proctor's testimony unfortunately, it doesn't go to the heart of the important constitution question which we are now confronted, namely did this drug, why is this drug sufficient, not only to create amnesia or loss of memory, but did it affect his will power.

But the evidence in the record, when looked at against the accepted pharmacological expert opinion, by which this evidence must be judged, is that this man was given according to this doctor's own testimony for the jury, 16 times more drugs than is recognized as a therapeutic dose.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: In other words what you're saying as I understand it correctly that the issue that you're arguing now when it went up the case -- as the case was tried, and as it went up to the Supreme Court of Illinois, didn't figure very heavily?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well not as carefully as I'm doing it here.
If we argued it, for instance I was appointed to represent this petitioner, when he was sentenced to death.
I argued this question in the Supreme Court of Illinois, the involuntariness of this confession.

But the actual analysis of this drug in the fashion I'm doing it now, I have no independent recollection of having done it because at that time, the argument was, was this a voluntary confession in view of the fact that he was under the influence of the drug.

And that is why when Your Honors denied certiorari, we went back and filed a post-conviction petition in the hope, in the course of the state proceedings and the petitioner is here now, in the course of the post-conviction petition, I would then have had the opportunity to have demonstrated to the trial judge that the very drug that had been told him was a normal therapy for narcotic addicts and the withdrawal system was in fact a powerful mediatric that paralyzes the eye muscles, causes amnesia, the loss of the -- of the this limb because hyoscine is said to be an autonomic blocking agent.
It had the capacity to separate the Central Nervous System from the ordinary organs of the human body.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And was this canvass at the post-trial, at the post-conviction proceeding in Illinois?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: It was not Your Honor and the reason for that was this.

The position taken by the State's Attorney was that the decision on writ of error was res judicata and the substance of the Supreme Court opinion on that was that all these questions had been decided.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But is there -- excuse me?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because I -- because I read the quotation of the post-conviction proceedings that they didn't quite (Inaudible) they said that (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's what they -- that's all I understood Your Honor.

They said that because we have doctor and new lawyer at criminal law that if a writ of error proceedings have instituted and completed, all the questions which could have been raised are taken within the scope of writ of error and the -- the -- the substance of the opinion of the Supreme Court of Illinois on the post-conviction petition was to tell me that all these questions you're now raising, we decided it anyway.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I'm -- my comment as elicited was invoked by the quotation in state's brief on page 26 in dealing with the pertinent portion of the order denying post conviction relief and it appears for me, (Inaudible) be guided by that.
Apparently, the point that was made was that there was a confusion as to be name of this drug and no mention is made to these other things.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well, but --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Even assuming -- the Court (Inaudible) they're assuming they could escape the doctrine of reasonable (Inaudible) but it then deals with that point on the merits from which I am referred, there is no other points to get (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: But if Your Honor will look at the post-conviction petition and the affidavits of this petitioner, the post-conviction -- was much broader than this narrow conclusion reached by --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where you at post-conviction in Illinois offer to introduce new evidence?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And if it was refused -- you were refused to make this pharmacological proof?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right Your Honor, on a motion to dismiss by the State's Attorney.

The motion to dismiss in a post-conviction and petition had the same effect as any motion to dismiss, affirmative allegations of petition appealing and the motion dismissed by the State's Attorney was sustained and then I took a write of error to Supreme Court of Illinois and then they wrote this memorandum opinion.
Now, I may pause here to say --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, have you -- did you -- but only to be a stickler to the murder case likely the state, but did you presented -- one of the questions presented that you weren't allowed in the post-conviction proceedings to introduce claimed relevant testimony?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: I'm sorry.
I didn't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did you raise one of the questions that we had to consider this question that you were shut off from introducing relevant evidence in the post-conviction proceeding of Illinois?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well, if --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They don't have to give post-conviction proceedings subject to the Constitution.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But if they do what you're now saying is that you were denied the due process in not being allowed to introduce relevant evidence, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's the effect of it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but there was no such question presented by you.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: In the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Here, here.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: In the course of these proceedings.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well, but the habeas corpus application contained all those allegations.

In our habeas corpus petition, all these facts were alleged including the -- the reliance upon this doctrine by the Illinois Supreme Court and we raised that question in the -- in the habeas corpus application and that is one of my -- my complaints about the dismissal of the petition for habeas corpus in the District Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I've questioned all this because I feel as I do about Layer and I notice while you drew a defense from Justice Schaffer on the ground that the administration of the drug in and on of itself destroyed -- rendered the confession not voluntary.
There's no suggestion by him in his dissent about the Layer situation.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's true Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because if that's -- I say again, I'm so alert about that problem that I had troubled you with these specific questions.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: I understand Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Leighton, may I ask you this? Did I understand you that (Inaudible) about 225 in the (Inaudible) heroin.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Heroin, that's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And after his arrest, he was not questioned at all until about 8:45 (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well, may I say Your Honor.
When I said a moment ago, there's nothing crucial.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yeah, that's what (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, what I wanted to ask is this.

Is there anything in the record to indicate how long it would be equitable a man took the dosage such as he took prior from his arrest before he would show these withdrawal symptoms and the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well, the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- the substance as the record seems to show (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton

turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren

turn.text: And 8:45 or 9:00 when the district attorney was waiting for him in the other room.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: The only testimony, the only evidence is the testimony of Dr. Mansfield who claimed some familiarity with the matter, he diagnosed the petitioner and found he was suffering from withdrawal symptoms, and his testimony appears first on page 214 of the type written record and again on pages -- beginning with the pages of 975 of the record before the jury and there seemed to be no question to mind of Dr. Mansfield that this petitioner was suffering a normal withdrawal symptom reaction at the time he examined him.
And I assume from this that the time that he reacted in this fashion is the normal time to be expected from a self-inflicted injection, say about 12:00 or the day before, you see.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This is about 20 hours.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: About 20 hours and no one seemed to question -- there seemed to be no dispute here that this petitioner was in the withdrawal symptom and that it was normal under the circumstances.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And what you're -- what you're putting to the Court is that the police officer with such lay knowledge -- as knowledge to be acquired as the laymen about condition of -- of narcotic addicts would know roughly speaking that within 20 hours the withdrawal symptoms would manifest themselves.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That he also knew -- he also knew that relief would be required by a doctor. That he also knew that -- that a doctor would examine him, he would examine him, but he would give him this drug which had the deleterious effect and that the sum total of all these was the pre-arrangement that getting him in a condition of mind which precluded a voluntary emission of words, is that right?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's the case you make.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.
Now, -- I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible) from cases, the record sustains you.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes, it would.
But may I say Your Honor?

If I made a quote some words you uttered recently that to a man in prison, and I may paraphrase it, it makes no difference to him whose liberty is taken that is a result of a professional incompetence or professional malice.

Now, if you look at the record carefully as Your Honor observed recently, one who's held in secret custody can never prove by evidence which we otherwise would take us persuasive, what took place behind the closed door, one of the vices of secrete interrogation.
Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's in cases where the interrogation in and of itself --

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- precludes assuming that man is (Inaudible) or he's in a position of his packaging.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But here, that is ruled out so far as length of time is concerned.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And your main position as I understand is that the administration of this drug has such as physiological effect upon the human faculty that what takes place during the period of its operation is not the will at any true sense -- in any meaningful sense (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right Your Honor

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- which is a very different case --

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- from concocting a scheme whereby it should be put into that (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

Now Your Honor, that the point that I can't escape about this case is this and it occurred to me, I don't want to sound fictitious, but you see although this was New Year's Day, this was not a party celebrating New Year with Charley Townsend.
They were there for this whole purpose and this was the purpose of everybody concerned on New Year's Day at the second police district.
The reporter, he wasn't there admitted to record celebration of New Year festivities.
He was there to record a confession.
If there wasn't a confession, anticipated, if Your Honor please --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But wouldn't any -- wouldn't any district attorney who had the suspect -- a suspect as to murder beyond the alert and make preparations in the hope and or expectation even that he might need a stenographer, that he ought to be on the job.
I don't see anything sinister about that Mr. Leighton.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Not sinister Your Honor, but merely indicative of what was in mind of all persons concerned you see.
Now, when the doctor is called, this was not an act of humane kindness towards Charley Townsend.
They wanted Charley Townsend to get out to this distress condition so he could answer questions.
In fact, Mr. Janega testified and his testimony is in the record without contradiction that when he first saw Townsend, Townsend would not answer question because he couldn't.

His testimony appearing on page 439 of the type written record in on and that he asked the officer to get the doctor and the doctor said -- I mean the officer said -- Cagney said, “I've already called the doctor.”
My point is this.

If you look at what was going on and fit it into the scheme of what was the objectives in mind of all these polices officers and public officials, they only had one thing in mind to extract by interrogation, questions that will clear up these unsolved felonies.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But am I wrong in the thinking Mr. Leighton that if they had not summoned a doctor as he requested, if they had not given a medical release and then by sheer (Inaudible) is his pain get well through with it, yes I did it but you would then not only would but I should think it would be your duty almost to say that a man in that distressing -- distressful painful condition would not a man fit to make any utterance so that when you say they didn't do it for humanitarian reasons like most human conduct, there maybe conflicts of consideration, I should think that's a far cry from saying this was a concocted arrangement.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well, may I say this Your Honor. The courts below have taken the view that it was not a concocted arrangement.
All I'm saying is that when you look at the totality of circumstances that the only thing they were there for was to take a confession from Charlie Townsend.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And my question is I think of I have wasted -- I have taking time from your main proposition that the mere administration of drug in and off itself is to vitiate this confession.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.
That's the point.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's your -- that's the point of your brief.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's the point -- that's of the brief.
Now --

turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could I ask you mechanical question?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

I'm just asking --

turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Well, I wanted an opportunity since the -- the Illinois courts had denied the petition of that opportunity, I want an opportunity to demonstrate the very thing I'm arguing here that this was not a normal -- this was not a normal therapy of narcotic addict --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, all of this then goes really to expert testimony not produced in any proceeding in the Illinois.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter

turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan

turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter

We never got to the point where the offer of proof --

turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I'm not trying to quarrel with you.

Obviously, new counsel as you are coming in, capital case as it turned -- defined that everything that he contend of what should be said.

turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

Now, I like to just in closing with the time allowed --

turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

We came before --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Any argument?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton

He wouldn't listen at all.
We came before this Court and Your Honors vacated to Judge Igoe's dismissal of the petition because he had not followed Jennings versus Ragan.

I then argued before Judge Igoe that we were entitled to plenary hearing with an opportunity to be heard including witnesses.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: By means of -- meaning of why when you said that?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: I mean that I requested it in terms of motion, I requested it then in argument against the State's Attorney motion to dismiss the petition a second time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You claimed you could rip open the whole proceedings, that what you claim?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You claim that you could rip open the whole proceeding.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right, and he wouldn't go to that point.

He finally ruled one day after we -- audit before him that he had read this state court records and he issued memorandum on it and he passed specifically on the request for an opportunity to be heard.
In the memorandum order of June 24, he specifically passed on that request.

At that point you see, I not had been given a chance to be heard, having urged for the opportunity to be heard and knowing what witnesses I have to produce but being denied the opportunity, we then took the appeal which is now before Your Honors.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well therefore, it is important for us if I may so to see exactly what your case you made out in this request that you called it to be heard --

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- in order to determine whether Judge Igoe was justified under the remand to say, “I don't have go outside, the record made in the state court,” isn't right?

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: Yes, it is important.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And he compared your -- your petition, your generalized allegation as to why you're in the District Court.

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter

I don't have to have a de nova hearing."

turn.speaker: george_n_leighton
turn.label: Mr. George N. Leighton
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor and then made no specific findings of fact or law.
Thank you.
